subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: Australia has committed to achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The recently elected Labor government has introduced and is in the process of legislating a reduction in carbon emissions by 43% below 2005 levels by 2030 and a reduction to net zero by 2050. Building on the Technology Investment Roadmap (TIR), Australia’s flagship long-term clean energy policy announced in 2020, the government has introduced their ‘Powering Australia’ plan which aims to increase clean energy penetration, support electric vehicle uptake, amend the safeguard mechanism, support industry decarbonization and provide funding for transmission and grid upgrades. The details of this policy are yet to be fleshed out.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Nearly all state governments in Australia have a net-zero target, and various mechanisms in place to get there. Targets, funding, and ambition differ by state, resulting in a complicated patchwork of state-based programs to reduce power and transport sector emissions. Many states have ambitious targets and are driving significant change through the announcement of their Renewable Energy Zones (REZs) and renewable energy auction programs.

Australia had committed to a 26-28% reduction on CO2 emissions from 2005 levels by 2030 and is now in the process of raising this to 43%. This targets economy-wide emissions reduction commitments, covering all sectors and gases included in Australia’s national inventory.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: Australia does not have any policies to phase out fossil fuels. There has been a rapid influx of new renewable energy generators, but coal generation still makes up the backbone of electricity provision. However, coal’s share in the power mix is declining as assets age, or are squeezed out of the market by cheaper renewable energy projects. The rising intra-day volatility in spot electricity prices, and a greater need for improved system strength, are signaling the need for more flexible capacity to enter the market. Policy makers and regulators have proposed a series of packages to support additional investment in dispatchable technologies like gas, batteries, or pumped hydro.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: By 2030, the Labor government models 82% of renewable penetration in Australia’s grid, driven by policy support. Investment in Australian clean energy has seen a boom and bust over the past decade, with investment in utility-scale renewables stagnating after its high in 2018. A lack of clear, long-term government policy and an increasingly hostile power market have deterred new investment. However, since the inauguration of the new government, more ambitious federal targets, and ongoing support from state governments, investment is picking up. Small-scale investments, supported by state-based feed-in tariffs and a federal (Small-scale Renewable Energy Scheme (SRES)), have frequently outpaced large-scale assets on an annual basis. Sovereign capital plays a limited but important role in investments, with the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and the Australian Renewable Energy Agency seeking to catalyze private capital into clean energy.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Australia’s wholesale electricity market has been extremely volatile over the past decade, and faced an unprecedented, chaotic start in 2022. Abnormally high power prices triggered price caps in the country’s wholesale power markets in June 2022, leading to a historical suspension of the whole system. Wholesale electricity prices in the National Electricity Market (NEM) rose an average of A$232-351/MWh in May 2022, an increase of 147-406% year-on-year.

As a result of soaring wholesale costs, the market regulator has signaled that electricity retail  tariffs will rise. The default market rate (DMO), the benchmark rate for tariffs offered by retailers, will rise by 7.2-18.3% in 2022-23.  Retail electricity rates paid by households remain high and are often among the highest in OECD countries. This is in part due to expensive network costs, which can make up 40% of a household’s electricity bill.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Australia’s power system is fully liberalized. The country has a competitive power market, as well as an open retail market. Any licensed company is allowed to own generation assets or to sell electricity to consumers. Companies are also permitted to sign power purchase agreements directly with power producers or utilities. Networks are split into transmission and distribution companies, and each is regulated as a monopoly over their jurisdiction. Several market operators and regulators are relied upon to ensure optimum outcomes for consumers, as well as system reliability and security. However, high power prices have resulted in tough conditions for Australia’s competitive retail energy market. Many energy retailers have already failed, and more are expected to follow.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Regulatory barriers to invest in Australian power generation remain low. However, recent issues on the grid are making it more challenging to connect large-scale assets on the east coast. Policy and market uncertainties have reduced the length and certainty of offtake agreements in recent years, with many new projects now seeking to operate on a quasi-merchant or fully merchant basis. Foreign investors in large and/or key infrastructure projects must proceed through a review process, but to date, this has only resulted in the knockback of planned acquisitions in certain distribution network assets.

subsections.title: EV market
text: A lack of political support means Australia lags its peers in electric vehicle (EV) uptake. Passenger EV sales accounted for 2% of total car sales in 2021. The federal government has done little to provide demand-side or supply-side incentives for the nascent EV market. There is no federal subsidy for EVs, nor emission standard pushing automakers to make more EVs available. Consumers are subsequently presented with a low range of EV models, while those models that do exist are usually more expensive than their combustion engine counterparts.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV  market remains at an early stage. Australia’s flagship transport decarbonization policy, the Future Fuels Strategy (FFS) announced in 2021, lacked a fuel economy standard, EV sales target or subsidy for low-carbon vehicles. State governments are filling the void with their own EV targets and subsidies but lack the strength to fully address transport emissions.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Barriers to doing business in Australia’s transport sector include securing enough electric vehicle supply to meet demand. Supply constraints are resulting in lower-than-expected, and erratic sales figures, as automakers do not ship many vehicles to Australia since they need to meet stringent fuel emission standards in other markets

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: Australia’s warm climate means that maximum building power demand usually comes in the summer months rather than the winter months. Simple air conditioning units are the primary source of cooling for Australian houses. States exposed to colder temperatures during the winter months, such as Victoria and Tasmania, have a far greater dependence on mains gas supply.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: Australia has two building energy efficiency standards in place as part of the National Construction Code. NatHERS is the minimum energy efficiency standard used for all new Australian homes; NABERS is the standard used for all new business buildings. Some states may choose to introduce additional standards. Australian governments have recently raised standards to require new residential dwellings to achieve the equivalent of 7 stars on the NatHERS.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Barriers to doing business in the building sector in Australia include high upfront costs, and little to no policy support − currently only at a state level − to incentivize building decarbonization.
